conclusion: Understanding the problem setup with a circular ring moving into a magnetic field to find potential difference between points a and b.
The ring has radius R, moves at velocity v, and enters a uniform magnetic field B with a 90-degree angle between points a and b.
The ring is moving to the right with velocity v and is partially inside the magnetic field at the position where ∠aOb is 90 degrees.
Emf is induced in the portion of the ring cutting the magnetic field lines, given by the formula \(\mathcal{E} = B \times l \times v\).
For the curved wire, the length l is the arc length inside the magnetic field.
The quarter of the circle from a to b is inside the magnetic field.
Emf induced between a and b is due to the quarter-circle arc inside the field.
Emf induced in the entire loop is zero because the magnetic flux through the loop is changing uniformly.
Considering motional emf for a straight conductor, \(\mathcal{E} = B \times l \times v\), where l is the arc length of the quarter-circle.
Arc length of a quarter-circle with radius R is \(l = \frac{\pi R}{2}\).
Emf induced between a and b is \(\mathcal{E}_{ab} = B \times \frac{\pi R}{2} \times v\).
Reconsidering the formula for motional emf for curved conductors, considering velocity component perpendicular to the field.
Considering the emf induced in the entire loop to find potential difference between points a and b.
Magnetic flux through the loop at any time t is \(\Phi = B \times A\), where A is the area inside the magnetic field.
Emf induced in the loop is \(\mathcal{E} = -\frac{d\Phi}{dt} = -B \times \frac{dA}{dt}\).
Finding \(dA/dt\) at the position where ∠aOb is 90 degrees.
The angle between points a and b is 90 degrees, and the area of the sector aOb is \(\frac{1}{4} \pi R^2\).
Area A is the area of the sector aOb inside the magnetic field.
